page_analysis.text_content:
Contextual front setbacks
Contextual setbacks apply if, and only if, the average of the existing setbacks on the same side of the block
is 30' or greater.
How to determine if a contextual setback applies using Fig 15 below, as an example.
Does block have
more than 3 lots?
(incl project lot)
Note: If block is more
than 600' long,
consider only lots within
600' (max. 10 lots).
Yes Exclude the following types of lots:
• Flag lot (C)
• Multi-family use w/ 3+ units (G)
• Corner lot facing cross street (H)
Is the number of remaining lots more or less
than 5 or more?
Yes
Exclude the smallest and largest
setbacks:
• Smallest (D)
• Largest (E)
Find the average of the remaining
lots (incl. subject lot). If greater
than 30', it applies.
30 (A)
33 (B)
+ 35 (F)
98 ÷ 3 = 32.7
Fig 15 Example of a block with a contextual setback of 32.7'

visual_elements.description: A flowchart illustrating the process to determine if a contextual setback applies. It starts with a question 'Does block have more than 3 lots? (incl project lot)'. If 'Yes', it leads to 'Exclude the following types of lots: Flag lot (C), Multi-family use w/ 3+ units (G), Corner lot facing cross street (H)'. Then it asks 'Is the number of remaining lots more or less than 5 or more?'. If 'Yes', it leads to 'Exclude the smallest and largest setbacks: Smallest (D), Largest (E)'. Finally, it instructs to 'Find the average of the remaining lots (incl. subject lot). If greater than 30', it applies.' A calculation box shows '30 (A) + 33 (B) + 35 (F) = 98 ÷ 3 = 32.7'. A 'Note' box is also present: 'If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' (max. 10 lots).'
visual_elements.location: Top and middle sections of the page

visual_elements.description: A block plan showing eight distinct lots (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H) with various building types and setbacks. Lots A, B, D, E, F are labeled 'Single-Family'. Lot C is labeled 'Flag lot'. Lot G is labeled 'Multiple-Family (3 + units)'. Lot H is labeled 'Lot fronts onto other street'. Setback measurements are indicated for lots A (30'), B (33'), D (20'), E (37'), F (35'). Lots C, G, H have diagonal lines crossing them, indicating exclusion. Lot H also has 'na' for setback and 'Street sideyard' indicated. A key is provided for 'Lot line', 'Sidewalk', 'Curb', 'Required setbacks', 'Buildable area', and 'Existing house'.

technical_specifications.parameter: Minimum average existing setback for contextual setbacks to apply
Maximum block length for lot consideration
Maximum number of lots to consider within 600' block length
Number of lots used for average calculation

subheadings: How to determine if a contextual setback applies using Fig 15 below, as an example.

additional_notes: Page number '21' is present at the bottom right corner.
The text 'Contextual setbacks apply if, and only if, the average of the existing setbacks on the same side of the block is 30' or greater.' is highlighted with a grey background.
